unittitle.value: Praeger Department of Parks survey and photographs

extent.value: in one manuscript box and three record cartons.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Praeger Department of Parks survey and photographs date from 1934 and measure 3.42 linear feet. The Praeger survey documents every park, playground, and gore in New York City at the time of the study, as well as undeveloped land owned by the parks department. The survey and photographs show the parks of New York City on the eve of improvements and development funded by the Works Progress Administration.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Praeger Department of Parks survey and photographs, V1974.003, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Source and date of acquisition for this collection are unknown. This collection was accessioned in 1974.

In 1934, Mayor Fiorella LaGuardia united each of the five New York City borough parks departments under a new city-wide Department of Parks. That year, under the direction of commissioner Robert Moses, the department conducted a study titled "Comprehensive Survey of the Parks and Playgrounds in New York City," documenting all public spaces in the city overseen by the parks department. The study was conducted by Emil Praeger (1892-1973), chief engineer for the Department of Parks.

The collection is arranged by borough, then alphabetically by park name. Photographs of Brooklyn parks are stored separately from the bulk of the collection and are also available in the library's image database. The collection covers parks in 36 Brooklyn neighborhoods with 231 images.
